jeopardy_round: THE LAST HALF OF THE 20th CENTURY
SO YOU WANT TO JOIN THE LAPD

(2, 1).clue: German Lotte Reiniger pioneered animation using these dark cutouts on a light background

(4, 1).clue: This canned tuna company has been using a mermaid on its logo since 1952

(5, 1).clue: To join the LAPD you must be younger than 35, but at least this age at the time of hire

(6, 1).clue: A doctor who may be summoned at any time, especially by phone

(1, 2).clue: In 1990 Guillermo Endara became Panama's president after this strongman surrendered to U.S. officials

(2, 2).clue: The first British feature-length cartoon was a 1955 version of this beastly Orwell novel

(3, 2).clue: Under the name Maxwell Grant, Walter B. Gibson created this hero who could cloud men's minds

(4, 2).clue: This fast food chain told us to "Save the Chickens...Eat a Whopper"

(5, 2).clue: During the physical abilities test, this must be maintained for 30 seconds while standing on a platform

(3, 3).clue: Day job of the mystery-solving character Roger Dowling

(4, 3).clue: The unofficial theme song of this Warner Brothers blabberbeak is "Camptown Races"...doo dah

(5, 3).clue: Of weight, height or hearing requirements, the one dropped by the LAPD as of March 1997

(6, 3).clue: Getting British unemployment benefits begun in 1911

(1, 4).clue: In 1961 military leaders killed this Caribbean nation's dictator Rafael Trujillo

(2, 4).clue: Like George Pal's "Toons", director Ladislas Starevich was best known for animation using these 3-D figures

(3, 4).clue: FDR & Isaac Asimov were among members of the BSI, this group of Sherlock Holmes fans

(4, 4).clue: It's often performed at wedding receptions

(6, 4).clue: Like woman Penelope Cruz in a 2000 film title

(1, 5).clue: In the 1980s Bulgaria ordered this ethnic minority from a neighbor to the southeast to take Slavic names

(2, 5).clue: In the 1950s the Zagreb School in this country gained notice for its unDisneyfied style

(3, 5).clue: In 1972 Faye Marder married this man; in 1985 they each put out their first mystery novels

(4, 5).clue: Created by Jay Ward & Bill Scott, his secret identity was Henry Cabot Henhaus III

(6, 5).clue: Acting as judge in a trial or not picked to participate in your team's baseball game

(1, 1).clue: He's the late religious leader & political figure seen here

(2, 1).clue: You can toss a ball with a flick of this because the carpal bones articulate with the radius & ulna

(3, 1).clue: In an ad for these khakis, a couple chases a mouse & ends up keeping it as a pet

(5, 1).clue: The homing type of these carried Olympic news in ancient times & U.S. Army messages in the 20th century

(6, 1).clue: Circus folk call this animal a "convict" (no offense; just think of its appearance)

(1, 2).clue: Founder of her own AnGeL Ministries, Anne Lotz is the daughter of this famous evangelist & his wife Ruth

(2, 2).clue: A bone called the vomer makes up much of this dividing wall in your nose

(3, 2).clue: Claymation California raisins danced to this Marvin Gaye hit

(2, 3).clue: From the Latin for "to chew", it's the technical name for the bone seen here

(3, 3).clue: In the '80s a sleazy salesman named Joe boasted that this car make had "more seats than the Astrodome"

(6, 3).clue: To toot up means to get the crowd's attention with this object heard here

(1, 4).clue: In his "day", the early 1900s, this baseball player turned preacher is estimated to have converted 300,000 people

(2, 4).clue: Moving up the spine, you have 5 lumbar vertebrae, 12 thoracic vertebrae & 7 of these in the neck
